title.narrative: Shelter Assistance for Empowerment and Resilience (Safer) / Envelope 1

description.narrative:
In line with this allocation’s Strategic Envelope One, the strategic objectives of relevant clusters, and building on GC and ATAA’s experience in the Dana subdistrict, considered to have the highest number of IDPs and informal settlements in Syria, GC and ATAA are planning to implement multi-sectoral interventions to improve shelter conditions for 228 most vulnerable households (HHs). GC and ATAA will target those who have been in prolonged crisis in IDP sites in Dana subdistrict, living in inadequate shelter conditions and are unable to improve their shelter for improved protection, privacy, dignity, and accessibility. These will be mainly in tented sites where HHs in old torn tents for over two years, or those living in flood prone sites will be assigned to a new site with better dignified shelter conditions. The newly established site will follow the Dignified and Safer Living Conditions Guidance developed by the SNFI Cluster. The planned intervention will include establishing 228 dignified shelter units with all associated shelter and WASH infrastructure and education facilities.
The proposed solution is cost effective and includes constructing improved temporary shelter units with sandwich panels for the walls and roof, while the latrines will be from concrete block for walls. Taking into consideration the available area per person in tents, we will be able to increase the living space per person. The associated infrastructure work includes site preparation, land levelling, road gravelling, the installation of a sewage network, a water network, elevated water tank, fencing, solar lamp posts, garbage bins, and an education center. The implementation will be through local Syrian contractors.
GC and ATAA have already secured the public land required for implementing this intervention in Selwa Community, close to the highest IDP population clusters in NWS. We will be considering merging IDP tented sites in Selwa in close proximity to the secured public land into one organized site. The proposed dignified shelter unit is responsive to the protracted displacement resulting from the prolonged crisis. It is an efficient and an accepted shelter solution by the community, since it provides more privacy and protection against weather elements, and has a longer lifespan compared to tents, which are more expensive as they require replacement almost every season.
Proposed activities will be implemented through a strong partnership between GC and ATAA. GC will provide technical oversight, overall program management, donor relation management and reporting, capacity building and monitoring for ATAA, and will operate the Feedback Mechanism (FBM), one of GC’s methods to prevent sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA) and improve accountability to affected populations (AAP). ATAA will conduct community outreach, beneficiary selection, and market assessments and will supervise implementation.
